translation.en: I can still remember laying in my bed,
translation.ko: 지금도 기억이 생생해요 전 침대에 누워서

translation.en: my little night-light on, crying over this.
I was so overwhelmed by this story.
Misha Defonseca checked every single box
for the type of woman that we looked for to interview on Exceptional Women.
I'll just take a beat and then turn. I got you. Okay.
translation.ko: 호흡 한 번 하고 시작할게요 됐어요, 가죠

translation.en: Stand by.
Her story originated in Belgium,
but she was living in Millis, Massachusetts,
20 miles away from the radio station.
You wanna give me a countdown?
[radio producer] Three, two, one.
[Candy O'Terry] Sometimes a story is so astonishing it seems unbelievable.
translation.ko: 너무 놀라운 이야기를 들으면 믿어지지 않을 때가 있죠

translation.en: Sometimes the sadness one person feels is so big, it's overpowering.
translation.ko: 어느 한 사람이 느낀 슬픔이 너무 막대할 때 감당이 안 되기도 해요

translation.en: And sometimes courage is so monumental, it humbles you.
translation.ko: 너무나 거대한 용기 앞에서 겸허해질 때도 있죠

translation.en: [Pat Cunningham] Back in the late '80s, we had been living in Millis for 37 years.
Pretty much everybody knew everybody.
And we had new neighbors.
They were a couple from Belgium, Maurice and Misha.
There's a saying in Millis, "Small town, big family."
translation.ko: 밀리스엔 그런 말이 있어요 '작은 동네, 대가족'

translation.en: It's a small-knit community, and we became friends.
translation.ko: 친화력 강한 공동체에서 우린 친구가 됐죠

translation.en: You want a little kiss?
[Pat] Misha was a very nice person. Very friendly, um, caring.
translation.ko: 미샤는 정말 좋은 사람이었어요 상냥하고 정이 많았죠

translation.en: I had never met anybody that had a relationship with animals as did Misha.
translation.ko: 미샤처럼 동물을 잘 다루는 사람을 본 적이 없었어요

translation.en: There were many, many cats.
Eccentric personality, for sure.
I was there one day having tea,
and she told me about her life during the war and so forth.
translation.ko: 전쟁 나고 그 후에 살아온 얘기를 들려줬어요

translation.en: She went into some detail.
[Candy over radio] Let me bring you into the life of a little girl named Misha.
translation.ko: 미샤라는 어린 소녀의 인생으로 들어가 봅시다

translation.en: She was waiting for her father to pick her up from school one day,
translation.ko: 하루는 학교 끝나고 아빠가 데리러 오시길 기다렸지만

translation.en: and he never came.
My mouth just dropped on the floor.
[Candy] Instead a woman tapped her on the shoulder and said, "Come with me."
translation.ko: 대신 한 여자가 어깨를 두드리며 '나랑 가자'고 했어요

translation.en: This little girl was taken into a home with a family she didn't know.
translation.ko: 어린 소녀는 모르는 가족의 집에 따라가게 됐어요

translation.en: She was given a new name and different clothes.
translation.ko: 새 이름을 얻고 다른 옷을 입었습니다

translation.en: [Candy] When she was only seven years old,
she walked alone for years,
through Nazi-occupied countries, across thousands of miles,
translation.ko: 나치가 점령한 국가들을 통해 수천 킬로미터를 넘나들며

translation.en: in search of her deported parents.
Misha is now a grown-up Jewish woman
translation.ko: 이제 미샤는 유대인 성인 여성이 되어

translation.en: living in the Boston area. She's a Holocaust survivor.
translation.ko: 보스턴 지역에 살고 있어요 홀로코스트 생존자죠

translation.en: And she's here to tell her astonishing story
translation.ko: 용기와 생존에 관한 경이로운 이야기를 전하러

translation.en: of courage and survival.
I think about my parents every day.
My mother's name was Gerusha,
and my father, Robert.
Reuven in Hebrew.
But our surname,
I don't think I ever knew.
I never discovered what became of my parents.
Not where they went or how they died.
To this day, I do not know.
[director] Settle, everybody, please.
So, Misha, tell me the story of the first time
you spoke about your experiences.
One day…
in a synagogue…
on the occasion of Yom HaShoah, the day of remembrance…
translation.ko: 홀로코스트 추모의 날인 욤 하쇼아 날이었죠

translation.en: I was asked to talk about me and my story.
translation.ko: 저와 제 이야기를 들려달라는 요청을 받았습니다

translation.en: My husband convinced me to do it,
telling me it would free me.
When I went up to the bimah,
I suddenly realized that I was going to speak for the first time.
translation.ko: "미샤 디폰세카" 갑자기 실감이 났어요 이 이야기를 처음으로 털어놓게 됐구나 하고요

translation.en: I burst into tears.
And slowly, snatches, I began to tell.
I was cold and I had to keep going
one step at a time.
That is survival.
You have to go forward
one step at a time.
I was, like, mesmerized.
People never knew about her being a Holocaust survivor.
translation.ko: 미샤가 홀로코스트 생존자인 줄은 아무도 몰랐어요

translation.en: I had tears in my eyes.
She was hungry. She was cold.
She was lonely. She wanted her parents.
How did this person survive?
[Misha Defonseca] I told myself,
"They think I'm alive."
"If they think I'm alive, I can't let them down."
"So I have to keep going."
[Jane Daniel] You could've heard a pin drop.
Everybody there was just completely entranced with her story.
translation.ko: 거기 있던 사람들 모두 미샤의 이야기에 홀려버렸죠

translation.en: [Jane] I never expected that I was gonna hear what I heard.
translation.ko: 그런 얘기를 듣게 될 줄은 상상도 못 했어요

translation.en: When Misha was seven years old, her parents were arrested by the Nazis,
and she was told that they had been deported.
She was placed in the care of a Catholic family
called de Wael.
So it was a safe place for her.
They gave her a new identity, Monique de Wael.
translation.ko: 그 사람들이 모니크 드월이라는 새 이름을 지어줬어요

translation.en: The deception saved her.
But she felt very alienated there.
[Defonseca] I ended up in a family that didn't love me.
translation.ko: 나를 사랑하지 않는 가족과 살게 됐어요

translation.en: That's the least you could say.
They hated me there. They would call me worthless.
translation.ko: 난 그 집에서 미움받았고 '짐덩어리'란 소리를 들었어요

translation.en: [Jane] There was a grandfather in that foster family who was kindly to her.
translation.ko: 입양된 집에 할아버지가 계셨는데 그분은 잘해주셨대요

translation.en: [Defonseca] He told me my parents were in Germany.
He showed me with a compass that it was in the east.
So Germany didn't seem that far.
translation.ko: 그래서 독일이 아주 멀어 보이진 않았어요

translation.en: [Jane] At that point, Misha made a tremendous decision.
translation.ko: 그 순간, 미샤는 일생일대의 결심을 했어요

translation.en: It turned her whole life upside down.
She decided, at the age of seven,
she was going to walk to Germany to find her parents.
[Jane] So she took her little compass and took some supplies
and started heading east.
I know exactly what I need.
I need the basic.
I need food, something to drink,
to have a knife for protection.
The first night I slept below a bridge.
It was not far from home.
It was absolutely naive when I think about it today.
translation.ko: 지금 생각해 보면 얼마나 순진했는지 몰라요

translation.en: On the map, Belgium seemed really small, and Germany was really close.
translation.ko: 지도에서 벨기에는 아주 작았고 독일은 무척 가까워 보였어요

translation.en: But if I went back, what would I find?
[Defonseca] Nothing was waiting for me back there.
And I had the idea to find my parents.
So I had to finish it.
Each time I approach a village, I see devastation.
[Jane] What she experienced as a child,
having to hide from the Nazis,
being alone in the forest,
having to steal food,
freezing temperatures…
She had had a nightmare childhood.
She had been traumatized by this.
[Defonseca] Killing…
I saw killing.
[Defonseca] The dead people.
It was really desperate.
[Defonseca] I dreamed of seeing my parents.
So I stayed deeply in the woods away from the war.
translation.ko: 전쟁과 마주치지 않도록 숲속 깊은 곳에 숨어 있었어요

translation.en: [Jane] When she was in the woods,
she was away from people being sent to concentration camps.
translation.ko: 미샤는 강제수용소로 끌려가지 않으려고 숲에 숨어 있었어요

translation.en: She was away from the horror that was happening in the cities.
translation.ko: 도시에서 자행되는 만행으로부터 멀리 떨어져 있었죠

translation.en: -[Jane] She was with birds and flowers. -[bird chirping]
She said that's what saved her.
[Defonseca] I completely gave in to the wildlife.
I saw this wonderful world with animals…
translation.ko: 경이로운 동물의 세계를 내 눈으로 봤어요

translation.en: in peace,
living normally,
eating just what they need,
not killing more than they need.
The balance was so… just right.
With animals I didn't need any words.
We were near each other
in silence
and understood without words.
[Jane] I was thinking, "This would make a fascinating book."
It was the early '90s.
I had a small publishing company.
When I say small, I mean tiny.
And I was looking around for a new project.
I was the first one that came along and said,
translation.ko: 제가 가장 먼저 그 이야기에 주목했어요

translation.en: "Could we make this even more public?" "Can we take this to another level?"
translation.ko: '더 널리 알릴 수는 없을까? 다른 차원으로 부각시켜 볼까?'

translation.en: "I could probably make something big out of this."
"There's a market for this story."
Because it had an amazing twist.
I remember I had just been caught by a farmer
who saw me stealing food from his farm.
I run away, full of fear.
And he ran after me.
When you run for your life, you run very hard.
And suddenly,
I had the impression that somebody was watching me.
I turn around and…
And I see this magnificent animal.
To me, it was like a huge dog.
The wolf seemed alone and I needed a companion.
translation.ko: 늑대 혼자 있었고 저는 동행이 필요했어요

translation.en: -[wolf howling] -It was a beautiful gray she-wolf.
I look in my bag for something to eat,
and I give a piece to the wolf.
And she doesn't take.
[Defonseca] It takes a lot of time,
but after a while, we would walk in parallel.
I was able to see its generosity…
translation.ko: 늑대의 넓은 포용력을 느낄 수 있었어요

translation.en: to appreciate the strength it had.
I was able to live with it.
She was like a mother to me.
Much later, it was a whole pack of wolves.
translation.ko: 한참 지난 후에는 늑대 무리와 함께 지냈어요

translation.en: I don't know how long I was with them.
They accepted me and protected me.
That was an amazing twist in her story. It was like, "Who ever hears of that?"
translation.ko: 엄청난 반전이 있는 이야기였죠 누구도 들은 적 없는 얘기였어요

translation.en: "Wow, this is quite a story."
[Joni Soffron] Misha was very different from most people I'd ever met.
translation.ko: 미샤는 제가 만나본 사람들과 무척 달랐어요

translation.en: My first impression was,
"She probably should've been an animal."
translation.ko: '이 사람은 동물로 태어나는 편이 더 잘 어울렸겠어' "조니 소프론"

translation.en: "Or her spirit is an animal."
She spoke about being accepted by the pack but being treated as a low-ranking member
translation.ko: 무리에게 받아들여지긴 했지만 낮은 서열 취급을 받았다고 했어요

translation.en: and that she had to exhibit submissive, low-ranking behavior
translation.ko: 서열 낮은 개체처럼 복종 행동을 보여줘야만 했대요

translation.en: in order to, uh… to be with them.
translation.ko: 그렇게 해야 같이 지낼 수 있으니까요

translation.en: Misha said the alpha male typically would eat first.
translation.ko: 미샤는 우두머리 수컷이 가장 먼저 먹이를 먹고

translation.en: The others would lay around the carcass waiting for their turn.
translation.ko: 나머지는 사체 주변에 엎드려 순서를 기다렸다고 했어요

translation.en: They would leave little scraps,
sort of in close proximity to where she was when they were finished.
translation.ko: 미샤가 있던 근처에 버려두고 갔다고 해요

translation.en: [Defonseca] Wolves eat ten kilos in one meal.
The leftovers were more than enough for me.
translation.ko: 먹고 남은 것만 해도 저는 배불리 먹었죠

translation.en: Get it.
Go get your dinner. It's right there.
[Soffron] We became very good friends.
You got it.
-You got it. Good girl! -[Soffron] She visited multiple times.
She would hand-feed them the pieces of meat.
I think they sensed in Misha
that she was a friend, as opposed to a foe.
translation.ko: 적이 아니라 친구란 걸 감지했던 것 같아요

translation.en: She had such a sense of being with them,
that it's like she belonged in there.
[Defonseca] I had no reason to stop walking.
It's what I did every day.
Day after day, month after month.
I have always the hope to find my parents,
translation.ko: 부모님을 찾는다는 희망을 한순간도 놓지 않았어요

translation.en: because I figure, "I have survived till now,
and if I have survived as a child, my parents must have survived."
And this belief makes me continue.
[Jane] I thought, this is a moral narrative.
translation.ko: 저는 그 이야기가 권선징악의 내러티브라고 생각했어요

translation.en: It's the battle between good and evil, the innocent child and the evil Nazis.
translation.ko: 무고한 아이와 사악한 나치가 겨루는 선과 악의 전쟁이라고요

translation.en: And the child survived.
It had mythic qualities to it.
And it could take my publishing company, Mount Ivy Press,
from a little local happening to a worldwide happening.
translation.ko: 소소한 지역 뉴스가 세계적 사건이 될 수 있다고 생각했어요

translation.en: So I asked Misha if she would be interested in publishing her stories.
translation.ko: 그래서 경험담을 출판하는 데 관심이 있느냐고 미샤에게 물었죠

translation.en: I brought it up very tentatively.
With everything I went through,
I'd learned to mistrust people.
[Jane] I don't think she was terribly impressed with me,
translation.ko: 저한테 별로 좋은 인상을 못 받았던 것 같아요

translation.en: and there was no reason she should be.
The kind of book I had published before was a legal financial book,
translation.ko: 그간 법률 금융 분야의 책만 출판했던 터라

translation.en: not exactly her kind of thing.
[Defonseca] For more than two years I refused,
but my community and my friends said to me, "Misha, do it."
translation.ko: 지역 주민들과 친구들은 달랐어요 '미샤, 책을 내 봐'

translation.en: "For future generations."
I found myself in hell again.
[Jane] It was a painful process,
but it was as if she was compelled to tell her story.
translation.ko: 미샤는 이야기를 알려야 한다는 책임감을 느끼는 듯했어요

translation.en: As if it was some kind of a catharsis.
Everybody was stepping up.
All the foreign publishers, one after another, after another.
translation.ko: 관심을 보이는 해외 출판사도 점점 늘어났고요

translation.en: We were selling the translation rights all over the world.
[Jane] My agent came back from California,
and said, "Disney wants this. Period. They want this."
translation.ko: '디즈니에서 이 작품을 원해요' 다른 말은 필요 없었죠 '그쪽에서 하겠대요'

translation.en: This was a case of a hot property.
[Jane] When the book was published in April 1997,
I said, "Let's see if we can get Oprah to do this."
translation.ko: '이 책으로 '오프라 쇼'에 나갈 수 있는지 보자'고 했죠

translation.en: Okay, this is one of my all-time favorite moments I'm having on television.
[Jane] At that time, Oprah had her book club.
If you were one of Oprah's books,
you had a guaranteed sale of a million books. It was like… That was the jackpot.
translation.ko: 백만 부 판매는 보장됐어요 대박을 칠 기회였죠

translation.en: Then we'll meet back here in a month, and we'll talk…
translation.ko: 한 달 뒤에 다시 만나서 얘기해요

translation.en: [Jane] And they said, "We're interested."
I love it!
So that's a big, big, big deal.
And we were beginning to say,
"We are heading into a monster bestseller here."
[Soffron] Jane Daniel told me that Oprah was considering doing the Misha story,
translation.ko: 제인 대니얼이 오프라가 미샤 이야기를 방송할까 고려 중이라며

translation.en: and could they send a production crew here to film Misha in with a wolf.
translation.ko: 제작팀이 와서 미샤와 늑대의 영상을 찍어도 되는지 물었어요

translation.en: So, I said, "Yes, of course."
I told Misha before we went into the enclosure,
this was an adult wolf, he was a very big boy.
translation.ko: 아주 덩치가 큰 수컷 성체 늑대라고요

translation.en: His name was Petro.
[Jane] Nobody went in but Misha.
The sound man had his boom over the fence. He didn't go in.
translation.ko: 음향 감독은 들어가지 않고 붐 마이크만 펜스 위로 뻗쳐 놨죠

translation.en: So, Misha squatted down, and she's feeding this one wolf cheese.
translation.ko: 미샤가 쭈그리고 앉아 늑대에게 치즈를 먹였어요

translation.en: And the wolf is very friendly.
Everything's going fine.
And then the wolf decides to put his paws on her shoulders.
translation.ko: 늑대가 미샤의 어깨에 두 발을 올려놓게 돼요

translation.en: [Soffron] Petro jumped up on her shoulders,
and he was much taller than she.
And then all of a sudden, very quickly, the wolf opened his mouth…
translation.ko: 그러더니 늑대는 갑자기 순식간에 입을 벌렸고

translation.en: [Soffron] …and put her whole head in his mouth.
Very gently.
Fangs on both temples.
[Defonseca] I felt no fear.
Nobody talked about the big bad wolf to me, you know.
translation.ko: 아무도 커다란 나쁜 늑대가 있다고 나한테 말하지 않았어요

translation.en: The wolf held her head for a minute. We've stopped breathing.
translation.ko: 늑대가 머리를 물고 1분쯤 있는데 우린 모두 숨이 멎었어요

translation.en: Oprah's producer with her eyes like…
[Jane] And then just as fast as it happened,
it was over.
And at that point, Misha rears back, lets out a big howl.
translation.ko: 미샤는 그 순간 뒤로 물러서며 늑대 소리를 크게 냈어요

translation.en: I get goosebumps telling this story.
From the back, way back in the back of the pen,
we hear…
…an "awoo" coming back.
When she howled, they immediately howled back.
translation.ko: 미샤가 울음소리를 내자 늑대들이 곧장 대답했어요

translation.en: [Jane] There it was. You could see.
There's the connection between the human and the wolf.
translation.ko: 그 사람과 늑대 사이에 교감이 있다는 걸요

translation.en: I saw it, you know. It was amazing. It was a shocking moment.
translation.ko: 전 봤어요, 정말 대단했죠 충격적인 순간이었어요

translation.en: So, they had got a lot of really interesting wolf footage,
translation.ko: 늑대와 어울리는 놀라운 장면을 많이 찍었기 때문에

translation.en: and I thought, "This is gonna make a great Oprah show."
The next step was that she was to go to Chicago for the studio portion.
translation.ko: 다음으로 남은 일은 시카고 스튜디오 녹화였어요

translation.en: [Soffron] Things were going swimmingly well.
And then, I began to see some tension
translation.ko: 그러다 알력이 생기는 게 보이기 시작했어요

translation.en: between Misha and Jane.
It wasn't very pleasant as time went on.
translation.ko: 시간이 흐를수록 영 모양새가 좋지 않았어요

translation.en: [Pat] The book wasn't selling very well,
so Misha and Maurice, her husband, were having financial difficulties.
translation.ko: 미샤와 남편 모리스가 경제적 어려움을 겪었어요

translation.en: So then she started selling things, from her house.
translation.ko: 그러면서 집에 있던 물건들을 팔기 시작했죠 "팻 커닝햄"

translation.en: And, um…
I felt bad that they were losing everything.
translation.ko: 가진 걸 다 잃는 부부를 보며 마음이 안 좋았어요

translation.en: [Karen Schulman] She kept saying, "I have no money. I have nothing."
translation.ko: 미샤는 줄곧 '난 돈이 없다 아무것도 없다'고 했어요

translation.en: "Jane Daniel's no good."
I felt saddened,
but then Misha was sitting at my table one night and said to me
translation.ko: 어느 날 밤, 저희 집 식탁에서 미샤가 얘기했어요

translation.en: she didn't wanna go on Oprah Winfrey.
I said, "Gee, Misha, I don't understand that."
[Jane] All of a sudden, Misha's not cooperative,
doesn't return phone calls, has one objection after another.
translation.ko: 전화를 걸어도 답이 없고 번번이 제 의견을 반대했죠

translation.en: She doesn't wanna go, it's inconvenient,
she needs somebody to take care of her animals at home.
translation.ko: 집에 있는 동물은 누가 돌보라는 말이냐

translation.en: [Defonseca] Jane made me so mad, so insecure.
translation.ko: 제인 때문에 너무 화가 났고 안정이 안 됐어요

translation.en: My husband said many times to her,
"With a survivor, you don't use that kind of attitude."
translation.ko: 홀로코스트 생존자에게 그런 접근방식은 옳지 않다고요

translation.en: [Jane] Come on. It's Oprah.
You find a dog-sitter or a pet-sitter or whatever.
translation.ko: 독 시터든 펫 시터든 뭐라도 불러놓고

translation.en: You make yourself available.
"No."
[Defonseca] Well, the memory, the bad memory, came back.
I have a nightmare. I was very anxious.
[Jane] We tried everything.
I wrote her notes and said, "This is a million sales."
translation.ko: 이런 편지도 보냈어요 '100만 권이 팔릴 기회예요'

translation.en: "No. No. No."
I thought, "This is crazy."
"Any other author would be falling all over themselves to do this."
translation.ko: '다른 작가였다면 기회를 잡으려고 기를 썼을 거예요'

translation.en: It never happened.
[Jane] A year after the book came out,
there's a knock on the door, and I'm handed a big package.
translation.ko: 누가 문을 두드리더니 커다란 서류뭉치를 주더군요

translation.en: It's Misha filing a lawsuit against me.
It's like, "Oh, my God." And at that point, everything stopped.
translation.ko: '이게 뭔 소리야' 싶었죠 그걸로 모든 게 멈췄어요 해외 출간 업무도 다 중단됐죠

translation.en: No other country wanted to do business with us.
translation.ko: 그걸로 모든 게 멈췄어요 해외 출간 업무도 다 중단됐죠

translation.en: We had a lawsuit attached to this project.
[Ramona Hamblin] The first time I met Misha,
I felt very compelled by the circumstances of the case.
translation.ko: 이 사건의 정황을 보며 강한 책임감을 느꼈어요

translation.en: It was clear to me
that several things had, um, been done that were improper, illegal, fraudulent.
translation.ko: "라모나 햄블린" 부적절하고 불법적이고 기만적인 업무 행태가 다수였어요

translation.en: Misha was asking for the return of the copyright to her name
and for all of the royalties that she was due for book sales.
translation.ko: 도서 판매로 얻은 인세 전액을 돌려달라고 요청하고 있었어요

translation.en: Jane Daniel saw in my life a gold mine,
translation.ko: 제인 대니얼은 제 인생이 황금알을 낳는 거위라고 보고

translation.en: and she took advantage of it.
[Hamblin] There was so much anger and bitterness
translation.ko: 제가 개입했을 때는 양측의 분노와 실망이

translation.en: between the parties by the time that I got involved,
there was not much room for negotiation.
And it was clear we were gonna be going to trial. It wasn't gonna settle out of court.
translation.ko: 법정으로 가는 건 확실했고 합의 가능성은 없었어요

translation.en: [Soffron] The sense in the courtroom was a lot of drama.
The atmosphere was pretty tense.
And then, of course, the money comes up.
[Hamblin] We found that Jane Daniel had set up a company in the Turks and Caicos,
translation.ko: 제인 대니얼의 회사 소재지는 터크스 케이커스 제도였어요

translation.en: so that royalties that came from overseas
went directly into her account and never paid royalties on them.
translation.ko: 한 번도 부부에게 지급된 적이 없다는 걸 알았죠

translation.en: We had documentation. We had royalty statements to show that she was paid.
translation.ko: 미샤에게 인세를 지급했다는 문서와 내역서를 갖고 있었어요

translation.en: We had canceled checks that showed that she was paid.
translation.ko: 인세가 지급된 걸 입증하는 지급필 수표도 있었죠

translation.en: So everything she was saying, we had documentation to refute.
translation.ko: 미샤가 무슨 주장을 하든 반박할 자료가 있었어요

translation.en: But she could speak no falsehood.
You know, "Where's the money?" And I think the jury was very sympathetic.
translation.ko: 돈의 행방에 대한 의문에 배심원단이 깊이 공감했어요

translation.en: [Hamblin] The jury was riveted.
In front of you is a person who'd survived the Holocaust as a child
translation.ko: 어린 시절 홀로코스트의 비극에서 살아남아 회고록을 쓴 사람이 눈앞에 있었으니까요

translation.en: and written a memoir about it.
They were engaged and absolutely enthralled by this story.
Misha was a good witness.
All what I lived is on the manuscript,
translation.ko: 내가 살았던 내용이 모두 원고에 있었어요

translation.en: because it's my life.
[Jane huffs] It just made me look like a monster.
translation.ko: 난 괴물 같은 인간이 돼 버렸어요

translation.en: And I thought, "This is not going well."
Jane was always fighting. She enforced what she want.
translation.ko: 제인은 항상 전투적이었어요 자기가 원하는 걸 강요했죠

translation.en: [Jane] It was a ten-day trial, and it was grueling.
The judge asks the jury, "How do you find on count one?"
The jury found unanimously for Misha on all counts.
translation.ko: 배심원단은 모든 기소 항목에서 만장일치로 미샤의 손을 들었죠

translation.en: I mean, ultimately, they came in with a massive judgment against me.
It was kind of mind-boggling to hear the number.
22.5 million.
So it was a very large verdict.
I am an optimistic person, but that hit me like a ton of bricks.
translation.ko: 전 낙관적인 사람이지만 하늘이 무너지는 기분이었어요

translation.en: I was blown away.
I said, "Are you kidding me?"
[Hamblin] The money damages against Jane Daniel
were largely based on Jane Daniel's testimony.
This was gonna be on Oprah, there was some contract with Disney.
translation.ko: '오프라 쇼'에 나갈 예정이라느니 디즈니와 계약이 됐다느니

translation.en: There were things that Jane Daniel testified to
to really elevate the level of damages
well beyond what would seem supportable for a book like this.
translation.ko: 이 책의 실제 가치를 훨씬 더 부풀렸어요

translation.en: So everybody paid attention.
People love a big verdict.
[Jane] Disney had fallen through. Oprah had fallen through.
There were no millions of dollars.
It's an untenable position to be in.
translation.ko: 누구도 편 들 수 없는 인물이 됐어요

translation.en: A cruel exploiter of an innocent Holocaust survivor.
translation.ko: 무고한 홀로코스트 생존자를 등친 잔인한 사기꾼

translation.en: You know, your world falls apart at that point.
[Jane] After the trial,
this was the lowest point in my life.
translation.ko: 제 인생에서 가장 바닥을 친 시기였어요

translation.en: I ended up going into therapy and being diagnosed with PTSD.
translation.ko: 정신과에서 외상 후 스트레스 장애 진단을 받았죠

translation.en: And I had horrible insomnia.
I was hanging on by my fingernails.
My publishing company was gone. The copyright was taken away from me.
I mean, I was destroyed at that point.
I ended up doing a post-mortem on what had happened,
translation.ko: "마케팅 및 광고 홍보에 협조" 시신을 해부하듯 지나간 자료를 낱낱이 뒤졌어요

translation.en: looking at it piece by piece by piece.
translation.ko: 시신을 해부하듯 지나간 자료를 낱낱이 뒤졌어요 "언쟁과 논쟁에 시간을 낭비하지 않았다"

translation.en: I was in my lawyer's office going through old records and documents.
translation.ko: 변호사 사무실에서 옛 기록과 자료를 찾아봤어요

translation.en: I had no idea what I was gonna find.
translation.ko: 거기서 뭐가 나올지 전혀 알 수 없었지만요

translation.en: I open a file, and it's Misha's bank account.
translation.ko: 어느 파일을 열었더니 미샤의 은행 계좌가 나왔어요

translation.en: And it's in Misha's writing, and it's her signature card.
And on there, it says…
…date and place of birth, filled in in Misha's hand,
translation.ko: "생년월일 - 1937년 5월 12일 출생지 - 에테르베크" 미샤가 수기로 쓴 생년월일, 출생지와

translation.en: and mother's maiden name.
All of a sudden, I suddenly get a flash.
[Jane] She knows who she is. She knows where she was born.
translation.ko: 미샤는 자기 정체를 알아요 어디서 태어났는지도 알죠

translation.en: [Jane] She knows who her mother was.
This was stuff she supposedly didn't know. She lost her identity in the war.
translation.ko: 모른다고 했었거든요 전쟁 통에 신원을 잃었다고요

translation.en: This doesn't add up.
[Jane] Clearly, she knew a lot more about who she was
translation.ko: 제게 말했던 것보다 뿌리에 관해 알고 있는 게 분명했어요

translation.en: than what she had told me.
translation.ko: 뿌리에 관해 알고 있는 게 분명했어요

translation.en: What else might not be true?
I had been owned by courts and lawyers.
My life had been turned upside down. I wanted my life back.
translation.ko: 내 삶이 뒤집어졌죠 인생을 되찾고 싶었어요

translation.en: [Jane] If I can prove that she's not who she's been saying she is,
translation.ko: 미샤의 정체가 따로 있다는 걸 증명한다면

translation.en: I can overturn this judgment.
It was the dead of winter. The days were short.
I was standing in my kitchen,
and I thought, "I have to do something. I have to do something."
translation.ko: 뭔가 조치를 취해야 한다는 생각이 들었습니다

translation.en: [Jane] I started recalling all the things that had happened.
How I had met her, what had happened then, what happened this…
translation.ko: 어떻게 만나서 어떤 일이 있었고 이때는 어떻게 됐고

translation.en: How did the lawsuit come about?
And then I thought,
"I'll write a book about the case. I'll do it as a blog."
I was writing my memoir of her memoir.
translation.ko: 미샤의 회고록을 만들었던 저의 회고록을 써 내려갔어요

translation.en: And maybe somebody will read it.
Talk about a long shot.
The next day, I get up,
I turn on my computer, and there's an e-mail.
translation.ko: 컴퓨터를 켰더니 메일이 한 통 와 있었어요

translation.en: And the e-mail says…
[Sharon Sergeant] "I think I might be able to help find out what's the real story."
translation.ko: '뭐가 진실인지 찾는 데 도움을 드릴 수 있을 거 같아요'

translation.en: I did a timeline of Misha from a variety of photographs.
translation.ko: 여러 사진을 토대로 미샤의 타임라인을 구성해 봤어요

translation.en: First from the book,
and then from other images on the Internet.
So I could get a sense of her life.
translation.ko: 그 사람의 생을 읽어낼 수 있었죠

translation.en: I wanted to know who she was.
Who is this person that has just ruined my life?
Each photograph I tried to analyze
and see what kind of information I could squeeze out of it.
translation.ko: 어떤 정보를 뽑아낼 수 있을지 분석했어요

translation.en: The first clue was Misha claims she was seven years old
translation.ko: 첫 번째 단서는 미샤가 위탁 가정으로

translation.en: when she was taken in by this foster family.
In the American book there was a series
translation.ko: 미국판 책에는 '폴리포토 사진'이라고 하는 여러 장의 사진이 수록됐어요

translation.en: of what they call polyphoto images.
translation.ko: '폴리포토 사진'이라고 하는 여러 장의 사진이 수록됐어요

translation.en: And the polyphotos were taken at that time.
And I looked at the photos, and I said, [clicks tongue]
"No, this doesn't look like a 7-year-old."
"This looks like a toddler, a three or four-year-old."
Big bow in her hair, frilly clothes and chubby, chubby cheeks.
translation.ko: 머리에 단 큰 리본과 주름 장식 옷 통통한 볼을 보고

translation.en: Something's wrong.
The next photograph I looked at
was a picture who Misha said was her foster grandfather and grandmother.
translation.ko: 그다음으로 제가 분석한 건 미샤가 양 할아버지와 할머니라고 했던 사진이었어요

translation.en: According to the narrative, he's a rustic farm man.
I did a close-up of the hands of Grandfather, which were manicured.
translation.ko: 할아버지의 손을 확대한 결과 손톱 손질이 깔끔히 돼 있었죠

translation.en: Did not look like a farm person's hands.
And he had a ring on one of his fingers.
Yeah, it was not the kind of thing a farmer would wear.
And then the little dog on Grandmother's lap,
that looks like a little house dog, not a farm dog.
So I thought, "Gee, that's strange."
And that's when I started comparing the French and the American book.
translation.ko: 전 그때부터 프랑스판과 미국판을 비교해 보기 시작했어요

translation.en: I was looking at names and places and dates.
That was the big red flag.
[Jane] She called me and she said,
"Do you notice that Misha's name that she used in the French book
translation.ko: '프랑스판에 나오는 미샤의 성이 미국판의 성과 다르다는 걸'

translation.en: is different from the name she used in the American book?"
In the American book, the name that she was given
translation.ko: 미국판에는 미샤가 위탁 가정에 가서 받은 이름이

translation.en: by the foster family that took her in was de Wael.
translation.ko: 미국판에는 미샤가 위탁 가정에 가서 받은 이름이 '드월'이라고 나와요

translation.en: What Sharon noticed immediately is the French book,
the foster family gave her the name Valle, V-A-L-L-E.
translation.ko: 위탁 가정에서 V-A-L-L-E로 쓰는 '발'이란 이름을 붙여줬대요

translation.en: Why would you have two different names?
[Sharon] There's too many discrepancies,
translation.ko: 새로 얻은 이름과 사진 등 앞뒤가 안 맞는 게

translation.en: between the name changes, the pictures, and so on.
translation.ko: 새로 얻은 이름과 사진 등 앞뒤가 안 맞는 게 너무 많았어요

translation.en: Fishy, yep. Definitely seemed fishy.
[director] Take a drink if you want. Just relax.
I know it's a nerve-wracking thing.
[Jane] If her story were true and I were doubting it…
translation.ko: 미샤의 이야기가 진짜고 제가 의심하는 거라면

translation.en: there's something particularly
vicious
doubt somebody who's telling the truth
about something awful that happened to them
and the callousness that it takes to say, "I don't believe you."
translation.ko: 진실을 말한 사람을 의심해서 '난 당신을 안 믿어'라고 하면 너무 무자비하잖아요

translation.en: And the harm you can cause by doing that.
That was in my mind.
On the other hand, what was also in my mind is, "So many discrepancies."
translation.ko: 하지만 동시에 이런 생각도 했죠 '앞뒤가 너무 안 맞아'

translation.en: Why would you be saying things that aren't true, unless you're crazy?
translation.ko: 왜 진실이 아닌 얘길 하는 걸까? 미친 것도 아니면서

translation.en: Maybe she's so traumatized that she's just lost her grip on reality.
translation.ko: 너무 충격이 커서 현실을 망각한 건 아닐까?

translation.en: How much did that explain? I didn't know.
translation.ko: 그걸로 설명이 되는 얘기인가? 알 수가 없었어요

translation.en: I needed a lot of answers at that point.
We need boots on the ground in Belgium.
[Jane] Sharon had a connection with a Belgian genealogist
who herself was a Holocaust survivor.
As it turns out, she grew up in the same area that Misha claims to have lived in.
translation.ko: 알고 보니 그분도 미샤가 살았다는 지역에서 성장했더군요

translation.en: During the war, I myself was a hidden child.
I went to a Catholic school,
and I became a very good little Belgian, Catholic girl.
translation.ko: 가톨릭 학교에 다녔고 아주 착한 벨기에 가톨릭 소녀로 자랐습니다

translation.en: I have no recollection of anybody telling me
what happened to my parents.
I have no memory at all.
I was about 40 and went through a sort of terrible breakdown…
which led me to find what happened to me, in fact,
translation.ko: 그러는 바람에 제게 일어난 일을 추적하게 됐죠

translation.en: and to my parents and my family.
And I started to make research.
I found out my father was deported to Auschwitz in September '42.
My mother was arrested in October in Brussels
and deported to Auschwitz.
I was told that they didn't come back.
So, I went by car to Auschwitz.
translation.ko: 그래서 저는 차를 몰고 아우슈비츠로 갔어요

translation.en: I saw the camp…
where there was not a single soul.
The chamber… The gas chambers were exploded.
I found some candles, what we call Jahrzeit,
still burning in the rubbles of some of the gas chambers.
Before leaving,
I had a Star of David done in dried flowers.
translation.ko: 말린 꽃으로 만들어 간 다윗의 별을 놓고 오려는데

translation.en: I just didn't know…
where to put it.
I couldn't put it at the monument.
So, finally, I chose the…
the little pond.
It floated there.
And I think that was the time that I…
[softly] Sorry.
Sorry.
…that I put my parents to rest.
My parents, my grandmother, my cousin.
[Jane] Evelyne is herself a Holocaust survivor
whose story was very much like Misha's.
translation.ko: 미샤와 굉장히 비슷한 사연을 갖고 있었기 때문에

translation.en: So she was the perfect person to find what was going on.
[Sharon] In the French book, the foster family had a surname of Valle.
And in the American book the foster family's surname was de Wael.
To reconcile the name changes,
Evelyne went through the city directories for the 1930s, 1940s.
[Evelyne] I came at least three days searching for the de Waels and the Valles.
translation.ko: 드월 집안과 발 집안을 찾으려고 최소 사흘은 도서관에 나왔어요

translation.en: The name Valle was not in the phone books.
The Valle name didn't exist.
De Wael, yes.
There were many de Wael. Many, many, many, many.
[Jane] So, now you start to think,
the French book was distributed in Belgium,
and if something about Misha's story is not true,
it would be important for her not to put her real name in that French book.
There would be somebody over there who would say, "I knew the de Wael family."
translation.ko: '드월 가족을 알아'라고 말하는 사람이 나올 테니까요

translation.en: "I know whether or not she was around, or did she disappear during the war."
translation.ko: '그런 아이가 정말 있었는지 전쟁 중에 사라졌는지 알아'

translation.en: [Sharon] The fact that she changed the name in France and Belgium
from de Wael to Valle,
suggests to me that she's trying to hide something.
translation.ko: 뭔가 은폐할 의도가 있다는 인상을 줬어요

translation.en: [Jane] Sharon and I both looked at this and said,
"Something's really wrong with this story."
So, at this point, the book had been taken over by a French publisher,
translation.ko: 그때는 프랑스 출판사가 책의 판권을 가져다가

translation.en: who had published it in 20 languages.
It was a huge bestseller all over Europe.
She was speaking to schoolchildren all over the French-speaking world.
translation.ko: 미샤는 프랑스어권 전역에서 학생들을 상대로 강연을 했어요

translation.en: [Marie-Claire Mommer speaking French] In 2005,
I was planning on creating
as a professor of psychology
a project on the story of this young child
who experienced all these adventures.

translation.ko: 프로젝트의 규모가 커져서 대대적인 전시회가 됐죠

translation.ko: 그러다가 미샤를 벨기에로 초청해야겠다는 생각이 들었어요

translation.en: to try and bring her to Belgium.
translation.ko: 그러다가 미샤를 벨기에로 초청해야겠다는 생각이 들었어요 "마리클레르 모메르"

translation.en: We watched her get out of the train.
It was a fascinating sight.
She was dressed in blue…
like a shining canary
with all its colors…
…with two,
no, three big suitcases!

very welcoming and very generous.

she collapsed.
[Defonseca, in French] I was not warned of this, so when I visited the exhibition,
translation.ko: 예상 못 했던 상황이라 전시회에 갔을 때

translation.en: I burst into tears because it touched me very deeply.
[Mommer, in French] She was so delighted to be there.
translation.ko: 미샤는 그곳에 온 걸 무척 기뻐했어요

translation.en: But on the other hand,
we saw the sadness come out
and the tears, the tears, the tears.
It was very emotional.
[in French] We were all really traumatized by her story
translation.ko: 저희는 미샤의 경험담에 너무 큰 충격을 받았어요

translation.en: and we all wanted to give a bit of joy to this woman
translation.ko: 이분께 조금이나마 기쁨을 전해드리자고 뜻을 모아

translation.en: by showing our creativity
and our courage, too,
to show what we felt.
[Jane, in English] In the book, Misha says that her parents
translation.ko: 책에서 미샤는 부모님이 함께 나치에 체포돼

translation.ko: 책에서 미샤는 부모님이 함께 나치에 체포돼 추방당했다고 주장해요

translation.en: Although she didn't know their surname, their first names were Reuven and Gerusha.
translation.ko: 부모님 성은 몰라도 이름은 레우벤과 게루샤라고 했죠

translation.en: So, the next step was, Sharon said,
"I have access to the Nazi records of deportations."
"Well, I will take those two names
and see if there are two people who were deported

[Sharon] When we examined the deportation lists,

[Defonseca, in French] "I missed my parents terribly."
"My face was covered in mud."
"I screamed… some nights, from the cold."
translation.ko: 추위에 떠느라 비명을 지른 밤도 있었어요

translation.en: "Later on,
I got a second chance."
"I survived because I trusted no one."
translation.ko: 난 아무도 믿지 않았기에 살아남을 수 있었어요

translation.en: "Because I avoided contact with humans."
[Evelyne, in English] During the war, the Jewish Defence Committee
had made lists of hidden Jewish children

translation.ko: 지금 그 명단이 전쟁피해자보호국 자료관에 있어요

translation.en: It was a real, real, real danger
that these lists would be taken by the Nazis.
translation.ko: 나치가 이 명단을 손에 넣는 날에는

translation.en: Children would be found,
and be, uh, killed.

There were four different booklets.
translation.ko: 각기 다른 소책자가 네 권 있었어요

translation.ko: 네 권이 다 있어야만 아이를 찾을 수 있는데

translation.en: But all four of them were in different places.
translation.ko: 네 권을 모두 다른 장소에 분산해 보관했어요

translation.en: If any Nazi found a single booklet,
they would not be able to trace the child,
but at the end of the war,
with the four different booklets,
there would've been a way to find whose child it was.
translation.ko: 어느 집 아이인지 찾을 길이 생기는 거예요

translation.en: And so I searched for Misha's parents.
No names of the parents.
So, I knew there that there was something wrong.
And in the lists of hidden children,
they didn't have "Misha," and they didn't have "de Wael,"
that is for sure.
She was not mentioned at all.
[Mommer, in French] Misha's story had a snowball effect.

translation.ko: 책이 수백만 권 팔려 나간 후였고

translation.en: And thereafter, we had to work to prepare the conferences and get her to them.
translation.ko: 우리는 미샤와 관련된 학회를 준비하느라 바빴어요

translation.en: So, we were always together.
At that time, she would often come back to our home.
translation.ko: 우리 집에 같이 간 적도 많았어요

translation.en: She would eat with us. She was like a member of the family.
We had dozens of events.

She was always welcomed by the organizers
and always with a lot of kindness and friendliness.
Everyone left the conferences
dazzled by this character.
[Evelyne, in English] I was stuck, really.
No findings but no proof.
No proof.
So that was the point where I thought that she could've been undocumented.
translation.ko: 그래서 기록이 남지 않은 아이는 아닐까 생각하게 됐죠

translation.en: Some children were hidden but not necessarily through organization.
translation.ko: 기관의 도움 없이 숨겨진 아이들도 있었거든요

translation.en: As extraordinary as her story was,
translation.ko: 미샤에겐 너무나 생생한 사연이 있었기 때문에

that she might have been a Jewish hidden child.
translation.ko: 숨겨진 유대계 아이가 맞는다는 가설을 포기하지 않았죠

translation.en: [in French] We are going to talk about this strange and wonderful story.
translation.ko: 기묘하고 신기한 이야기를 시작해 볼까 합니다

Hello.

translation.ko: 이야기를 전하러 직접 나와 주셔서 감사합니다

translation.en: [Jane, in English] Now the stakes go up. I start worrying.
translation.ko: 위험 부담이 더 커지니까 걱정되기 시작하더군요

translation.en: I will feel a lot of guilt, if this is true,
translation.ko: 사실이 맞는데 뒤를 캐고 있는 거라면

And what if it is true?

Hello.

translation.ko: 그 얘기를 반박하다니 얼마나 몹쓸 짓인가요

translation.en: And even if it's mostly true but not quite true,
how unfair to disrespect what she's been through.
translation.ko: 그 고난을 폄하하는 건 너무 부당한 짓이잖아요

translation.en: [in French] You have to go through all the tragedy
and all the horrors.
It's very painful.
I felt like I had been cast in a play that I didn't audition for.
translation.ko: 오디션에 지원한 적도 없는데 연극 무대에 선 기분이었어요

translation.en: I didn't want the part. I didn't wanna be in the play.
translation.ko: 그 배역을 맡기 싫고 연극에 얼굴을 비추기 싫었죠

translation.en: [in French] I have known hatred
and I have known the rage to kill
because it's my life or his.
It was devouring me.
[in French] Personally…
I live it every day.
This had taken over my own life.
[in French] I think about my parents every day, and for me,
translation.ko: 매일 부모님 생각을 해요 저에게는 아직도

translation.en: the Holocaust is every day. The memory stays with you every day.
[Jane] But I'd had this judgment hanging over my head for quite a while now.
translation.ko: 하지만 배상금 판결에 짓눌린 지 꽤 됐을 때였어요

translation.en: I had lost the appeal.
I was looking at the possibility of being completely wiped out.
So it was starting to get pretty uncomfortable,
but I needed to get to the truth.
So, when we had no Jewish records to support her story,
translation.ko: 미샤의 이야기를 뒷받침할 유대인 기록이 없다는 걸 알고

translation.en: the question is, maybe she's not even Jewish.

[Sharon] Misha Defonseca's bank record from the trial records
translation.ko: 재판 기록에서 얻은 미샤 디폰세카의 금융 자료에는

translation.en: said that she was born in 1937,

translation.ko: 어머니 결혼 전 이름은 돈빌이고 에테르베크에서 태어났죠

translation.en: [Evelyne] Etterbeek, a suburb of Brussels.

translation.ko: 그래서 저는 에테르베크의 다른 교회들을 찾아봤어요

translation.en: [Jane] So Evelyne went to the first one. The records weren't there.
translation.ko: 에블린이 첫 번째 교회에 갔는데 기록이 없다고 했어요

translation.en: [Evelyne] Went to another one…
[Jane] No baptismal record that matched Misha's information.
translation.ko: 미샤의 인적 사항과 일치하는 영세 기록이 없었어요

translation.en: [Evelyne] And to the third one in the area…
[Jane] As it turns out, the church had burnt to the ground.
translation.ko: 알고 보니 그 교회는 전소됐던 곳이었어요

translation.en: When we learned that, I thought… [groans]
"We're probably sunk now, because the records probably were destroyed in the fire."
translation.ko: '화재로 기록이 소실됐을 테니 이걸로 끝난 것 같군요'

translation.en: [Evelyne] But the offices, the presbytère,
was in an adjoining street.
They were preserved.
So, Evelyne was looking date by date by date, all the children born in that parish.
translation.ko: 에블린이 교구 출생 아동을 날짜별로 전부 들여다봤어요

translation.en: I knew two things:
Her date of birth, 12th of May, 1937,
and the mother's name, Donville.
And in that book, I found her.
"Monica Ernestina Josephine de Wael…
daughter of Roberti Henrici Ernesti de Wael
and Josephinae Germanae Barbarae Donvil."
The revelation was that Misha's father's name was de Wael.
translation.ko: 미샤 아버지의 성이 드월이었다는 게 확인됐어요

translation.en: So, at that point, it seemed that Monique de Wael was her real name.
translation.ko: 그래서 모니크 드월이 본명이라고 추정하게 됐죠

translation.en: It wasn't a name given to her by foster parents to hide her from the Nazis.
translation.ko: 나치에게서 숨겨준 위탁 가정의 성이 아니었어요

translation.en: It seemed like she was born Monique de Wael.
translation.ko: 태어날 때 받은 이름이 모니크 드월이었나 봐요

translation.en: She was a Catholic. She was baptized Catholic.
Her father was de Wael.
However, it wasn't proof conclusive.
Because in those days, they used to take names of dead children
translation.ko: 그 시절에는 죽은 아이의 이름을 빌려

translation.en: and give them to Jewish children, by way of hiding them.
translation.ko: 유대인 아이에게 줘서 은닉하는 경우가 있었거든요

translation.en: It was possible that the de Waels had taken in a hidden child

I needed further proof.
[director] So what did you do next?
[chuckles] Off the record, this is a good question.
-[crew chuckles] -[chuckling] What do I do next?
[Jane] Evelyne figured out, "All right, where else can I find that proof?"
translation.ko: 에블린은 어디서 증거를 찾을 수 있을지 생각했어요

translation.en: She would've gone to school.
I tried to find a school on the tram track that she mentioned in her book.
translation.ko: 책에서 언급한 트램 노선에 학교가 있는지 찾아봤어요

translation.en: [chuckles] And as I walked by, I hit the school.
The door was open.
I walked in and asked
if they had any record of someone with the name of Monique de Wael.
[Jane] So, we're biting our fingernails, to the point that they're practically bleeding,
waiting for this information.
Either we've got the records or we don't.
[Evelyne] And there on the register was her name.
"De Wael, Monique."
That was really the final proof, shall I say.
Both the baptism certificate
and her attendance in a school in Brussels.
I got to the phone, and I picked up the phone and it was Sharon.
And Sharon could hardly contain her excitement.
She practically screamed into the phone, "We've got the records! We've got the records!"

[Jane] Now I've caught her in a lie.
My life had been contaminated…
[crewman] End board.
[Jane] …by a whole spiderweb of lies.
[director] Take 15 minutes, everybody.
[Jane] And here it is, exposed as a hoax.
[Defonseca, in French] Could you pass me a bottle of water, please?
-Thank you. -[Jane] I thought,
"Now, the whole story that she has been telling in the book falls apart."

translation.ko: 그때 미샤의 진짜 정체는 따로 있다는 걸 알았어요

translation.en: [Jane] Not only was she not a Jewish child hiding in the forest from the Nazis,
translation.ko: 나치를 피해 숲에 숨었던 유대인 아이가 아니라

translation.en: she was a Catholic child safely enrolled in school.
She wasn't anywhere near wolves.
She was playing to an audience. She knew exactly what she was doing.
translation.ko: 관중 앞에서 연기를 했어요 무슨 짓을 하는지 본인도 알았죠

translation.en: Now we can see that this is not just a little white fib.
translation.ko: 이제는 가벼운 선의의 거짓말이 아니라는 걸 우리도 알아요

translation.en: This is a massive conspiracy over 20 years
to propagate something that was a complete and total falsehood.
translation.ko: 처음부터 끝까지 거짓인 이야기를 세상에 팔아먹었던 거예요

translation.en: This was not the real Misha.
[Evelyne] I had many feelings.
I felt angry. I felt disgusted.
I just saw the fake history, the fake identity,
a way to get money out of the Holocaust.
Somebody stole a very painful part of my life.
translation.ko: 너무 고통스러웠던 내 인생의 한 페이지를 누군가 훔쳐 갔어요

translation.en: [inhales deeply] I felt it for myself, for my…
for all the hidden children
and all the dead children through the Holocaust.
translation.ko: 홀로코스트 때 죽은 모든 아이들이 떠올랐어요

translation.en: For all the parents, for my parents, [inhales]
translation.ko: 모든 부모와 제 부모를 대신한 분노이자

translation.en: but in fact for all the Jewish community.
[Jane] At the point that we got those records, the book was a huge bestseller all over Europe
translation.ko: 기록을 찾던 시기에 책은 유럽 전역의 베스트셀러였고

translation.en: and the movie had just come out.
And the movie was called Survival with Wolves.
[male host, in French] There it is, the trailer of Véra Belmont's film.
It's very touching to see you both here, the real person and little Mathilde.
translation.ko: 실제 주인공과 아역 배우 마틸드를 한 자리에서 보니 가슴이 찡해요

translation.en: You seem very emotional.
It's as if you are reliving this story every time you see the film?
translation.ko: 영상을 보실 때마다 옛 기억이 다시 떠오르십니까?

translation.en: Yes, that's right.
That's right. It's very difficult.
translation.ko: 그럼요, 맞아요, 굉장히 힘들죠 마틸드의 연기를 보면서 본인의 모습과

translation.en: Do you recognize yourself in Mathilde's acting?
translation.ko: 마틸드의 연기를 보면서 본인의 모습과 닮았다는 생각이 드세요?

translation.en: Absolutely, absolutely. It's very well expressed.
She plays magnificently.
She conveys the emotions very well.
It was the thought of my mother that kept me going.
translation.ko: 저는 어머니를 생각하며 계속 걸을 수 있었어요

translation.en: There is a scene in the film which to me is extraordinary.
translation.ko: 유독 강렬한 인상을 남긴 장면이 하나 있어요

translation.en: The one where she falls out of the train and she says…
[in French] Cinema, with a beautiful film inspired by a true story.
[in French] You're great.
-You're a great actress. -[chuckles]
[in French] This story is very, very moving.
An incredible story and yet a true story.
[in French] Cut! Excellent.
[in English] It premiered in Paris.
"Based on a true story."
And here we're holding these documents.
translation.ko: 그런데 우리 손에는 그 서류가 있었죠

translation.en: So we thought, "Let's go with this. Let's put it on my blog,
and let's e-mail somebody over there in Belgium."
The next morning we got up,
it had broken front page of all the newspapers.
[newsreader, in French] A book, then a film,
supposedly an autobiography, but everything was false.
translation.ko: 자서전을 표방했던 책과 영화가 모두 거짓으로 밝혀졌습니다

translation.en: [in French] It was an incredible story, the story of a young Shoah survivor.
We had fired a truth bomb. It had landed.
translation.ko: 우리가 쏜 진실의 폭탄이 땅에 떨어졌어요

translation.en: [in French] Surviving with Wolves, the bestseller that inspired the film released last month…
And the whole fake thing blew up.
…is not a true story.
Everything is false.
It was a big scam.
[director, in English] House lights.
I came home, I immediately went to my computer,
I put in her name and there it was.
[reporter, in French] The beautiful story was entirely false.
translation.ko: 그러나 이 아름다운 이야기는 모두 거짓이었습니다

translation.en: In Belgium, her country of origin,
historians have discovered Misha Defonseca is actually Monique de Wael.
translation.ko: 출신국인 벨기에 역사학자들이 미샤 디폰세카가 실은 모니크 드월이란 사실을 밝혀냈죠

translation.en: I think I felt like my blood just drained from my body, you know.
How… How can this possibly be?
I was angry.
I was sad. I was hurt.
I felt betrayed.
I felt used.
She became that close a friend to me
that when we had a litter of pups born, we named one Misha.
translation.ko: 늑대의 새끼가 태어났을 때 미샤라는 이름까지 붙여줬어요

translation.en: It was just heartbreaking.
Absolutely heartbreaking.
-Hey, baby girl. -[wolf whines]
We were duped, just like the rest of you.
[Karen] That fact that she lied about her being a Holocaust survivor
made me cry.
Misha Defonseca played on sympathy.

Sympathy.
That's how Misha Defonseca was able to fool people.
translation.ko: 그걸 이용해서 사람들을 갖고 놀았던 거예요

translation.en: Sympathy.
[Pat] I burst into tears.
I just felt so taken advantage of and lied to and all…
Ugh! The lies and the bitterness and everything came out.
translation.ko: 거짓말에 당한 씁쓸함을 비롯해 온갖 감정이 솟구쳤어요

translation.en: Some of my neighbors did give her quite large sums of money.
translation.ko: 이웃 중에는 미샤에게 큰돈을 준 사람도 있었어요

translation.en: We're talking $25-30,000 to help her save the house.

The entire community…

translation.ko: 그 사람을 알던 이웃 모두가 관계를 끊었어요

translation.en: Everybody felt betrayed.
Yeah.
[Mommer, in French] There was a sort of anger that rose in me

The students who took part in the project,

translation.ko: 하지만 돌아온 대답은 '걱정 말아요 계속 당하던 일이에요'

translation.en: "It must be the doing of the publisher in America."

translation.ko: 그보다 더 이상한 일이 벌어질 줄은 몰랐죠

translation.ko: 혼잣말을 했어요 '소설을 써도 이렇게는 못 써'

"This is preposterous. This would not happen."
translation.ko: '억지다, 이런 일은 절대 없다'는 소리를 듣겠죠

translation.en: [Marc Metdepenningen, in French] Every journalist dreams of a scoop.
The question for me was,
translation.ko: 그 이야기가 가짜였다면 진짜 이야기는 무엇인지

translation.en: if her story is false,
translation.ko: 그 이야기가 가짜였다면 진짜 이야기는 무엇인지 "마르크 멧데페닝언"

translation.en: then what is her real story?
What I simply did
was go through the Brussels phone book
where there are approximately 400 de Waels.
So I started to call them one after the other.
And at the 44th or 43rd name,
I stumbled across a woman called Emma de Wael.
[Marc] My meeting with Emma, Misha's aunt,
was extraordinary.
She didn't go off in search of her parents?
translation.ko: 모니크가 부모를 찾아서 유럽을 횡단한 적이 없다고요?

translation.en: [in French] Good God, no.
She stayed with her grandfather and grandmother.
Emma told me
her niece had always been delusional,
that she would create imaginary worlds for herself.
I went and fetched her regularly
with the number 56 tram to Anderlecht
and brought her to Schaerbeek.
In the evenings, I took her back to Uncle Ernest.
[Marc] Emma de Wael told me the truth
translation.ko: 에마 드월은 전쟁 중에 진짜로 일어났던 일을

translation.en: about what happened during the war.
What happened to Robert de Wael, Misha Defonseca's father.
translation.ko: 미샤 디폰세카의 아버지인 로베르 드월의 이야기였죠

translation.en: [man, in French] Robert de Wael worked at Schaerbeek town hall.
He was really very patriotic
translation.ko: 애국심이 대단했고 예비역 장교 역할에 충실했어요

translation.en: and very engaged in his role as a reserve officer.
translation.ko: 애국심이 대단했고 예비역 장교 역할에 충실했어요 "장필리프 통되르"

translation.en: I met Jean-Philippe Tondeur by chance
but he had a lot of documentation
translation.ko: 미샤 디폰세카의 아버지에 관한 다량의 기록을

translation.en: on Misha Defonseca's father.
So I went to consult Robert de Wael's file.
translation.ko: 그래서 로베르 드월의 서류를 검토하러 갔죠

translation.en: [Tondeur] On 10th of May, 1940, the Germans invade Belgium.
[Tondeur] They crush the Belgian army during an 18-day campaign.
The king surrenders
and Belgium is occupied.
Robert de Wael joins the resistance…
…and begins to recruit resistance fighters.
[Marc] As a resistance fighter,
Robert de Wael
was involved in gathering weapons…
activating intelligence networks
and transmitting intelligence to the Belgian government
which had gone to London.
Unfortunately, Robert de Wael wasn't very discreet
translation.ko: 안타깝게도 로베르 드월은 레지스탕스 활동을 하면서

translation.en: about his activities for the resistance.
[Emma de Wael] He had a loose tongue.
He was proud of what he was doing.
Because I knew he had secret documents.
translation.ko: 비밀문서를 갖고 있던 걸 나도 알았거든요

translation.en: He even showed them to us at home.
My father told him to be careful,
that he was becoming careless.
He risked arrest.
He was denounced by a Nazi collaborator
and was quickly arrested.
[Tondeur] Robert de Wael, his wife and 41 arrested resistance fighters
translation.ko: 체포된 로베르 드월 부부와 레지스탕스 요원 41명은

translation.en: are deported to Germany…
and sent to the Brauweiler Prison in Cologne.
The Cologne prison had a very harsh regime.
[Tondeur] He is interrogated by the Gestapo.
He starts to scream.
Robert de Wael cracks.
[Marc] Robert de Wael made a deal in the Cologne prison.
translation.ko: 로베르 드월은 쾰른 교도소와 거래를 했어요

translation.en: This deal involved him
handing over the names of his fellow resistance fighters
translation.ko: 거기서 그는 레지스탕스 요원의 이름을 넘기는 대신

translation.en: in exchange for his wife being protected
and to once again see his daughter, Misha Defonseca.
translation.ko: 딸인 미샤 디폰세카를 한 번 더 볼 수 있게 됐어요

translation.en: [Tondeur] In August 1942, after betraying his fellow officers,
as the Germans had demanded of him,
Robert de Wael got one last opportunity to see his daughter.
translation.ko: 로베르 드월은 마지막으로 딸을 한 번 더 만났어요

translation.en: And that would be
the end for…
for Robert de Wael, who was later deported.
translation.ko: 후에 로베르 드월은 강제 추방을 당했고

translation.en: Robert and his wife Germaine would both die in the German camps.
translation.ko: 로베르와 제르맨 부부는 독일 수용소에서 숨을 거뒀습니다

translation.en: We called her "The Traitor's Daughter."
Because it was said that her father
sided with the Germans.
[Tondeur] The municipality of Schaerbeek would engrave a plaque
translation.ko: 스카르베크 지자체는 전쟁 중 사망한 레지스탕스 요원의

translation.en: in the name of the resistance fighters who died during the war.
Robert de Wael, whose name was listed last…
translation.ko: 로베르 드월의 이름은 맨 끄트머리에 올랐지만

translation.en: was later erased.
[Marc] On 22nd of February 2008, once things were very clear,
uh, we published Robert de Wael's whole story,
translation.ko: 로베르 드월 관련 이야기를 모두 공개했습니다

translation.en: the betrayal,
the falseness of Misha Defonseca's account.
And in the hours that followed,
a statement was issued.
This is Misha Defonseca's statement.
"They called me 'The Traitor's Daughter'
because my father was suspected of having spoken under torture."
translation.ko: '고문에 시달린 아버지가 비밀을 누설했다고 의심한 탓이다'

translation.en: "This book, this story, is mine."
"It is not the actual reality,
but it was my reality…
my way of surviving."
"I ask forgiveness."
"All I ever wanted was to exorcise my suffering."
translation.ko: '나는 오로지 내가 짊어진 고통을 떨치고 싶었을 뿐이다'

translation.en: [in French] I felt so rejected,
but I could not explain it to myself,
translation.ko: 하지만 나 스스로 납득이 안 됐어요

translation.en: neither to my grandmother or my grandfather.
I am not the girl I thought,
but there are times…
when I still hesitate.
I say to myself, "Did I or didn't I experience it?"
translation.ko: 스스로 묻죠, '내가 그런 일을 안 겪었단 말이야?'

translation.en: I have to think.
Particularly with animals.
Particularly with animals.
-[growling] -I can still see myself
rolling on the ground with wolves.
Have you seen my lovely wolves?
They will always be
my wolves.
I will be always at their side.
Even if I know the truth now.
I am at their side.
I got into a bubble, a world of my own.
translation.ko: 나는 내가 만든 허구의 세상에 빠져 살았어요

translation.en: And this world of mine was filled with animals.
Animals that defended me
against humans.
[Candy, in English] Listening back to this interview,
the first words in the intro to the show were…
translation.ko: 방송 인트로의 첫 멘트가 이렇게 나와요

translation.en: [on radio] "Sometimes a story's so astonishing, -it's unbelievable." -[mouthing along]
translation.ko: '너무 놀라운 이야기를 들으면 믿어지지 않을 때가 있죠'

translation.en: That's pretty astonishing. [chuckles] That those were the first words.
translation.ko: 저 말부터 했다는 게 무척 놀랍죠

translation.en: And then it turns out, it's not true.
I believed her.
I didn't see anything in those eyes
translation.ko: 그 눈을 보면서 사실이 아닐 거란 생각은

translation.en: that made me think she wasn't telling me the truth.
[Defonseca on headphones] Fear for me, at this time, was the German.
It was the…
[Candy O'Terry] All I was doing was looking for more truth
to confirm what I already believed.
translation.ko: 더 진실된 요소를 찾아 믿음을 확인받고 싶었어요

translation.en: In hindsight, it's chilling.
But for me, at that moment,
I was so respectful of someone's experience,
at what I think we all, as citizens of the world,
will recognize was the darkest time in the history of our world.
Far be it from me to question her.
translation.ko: 의구심을 갖는다는 건 엄두도 못 냈죠

translation.en: [Debórah Dwork] Questioning someone's claim to be a Holocaust survivor
translation.ko: 홀로코스트 생존자라고 주장하는 사람을 의심하는 건

translation.en: is very difficult.
One brings a great deal of diffidence to those claims.
translation.ko: 그런 주장 앞에서는 누구나 의심을 삼가게 되죠

translation.en: But the danger of believing everything
translation.ko: 하지만 모든 것을 의심 없이 믿을 때

translation.en: puts history
and the historical reality
of genuine survivors at risk.
In December 1996,
I got a letter and a manuscript from Jane Daniel.
translation.ko: 편지 한 통과 제인 대니얼의 원고를 받았어요

translation.en: That manuscript was Misha: A Mémoire
by a young girl during the Holocaust.
translation.ko: "데보라 드워크" 홀로코스트 시기의 소녀에 관한 이야기였어요

translation.en: I called Jane Daniel
to explain why this narrative just did not work.
translation.ko: 왜 이 서사에 일관성이 없는지 설명했어요

translation.en: I said to her,
"I would not publish this book."
I have thought a lot over the years
as to why Jane Daniel decided to go forward with publication.
translation.ko: 제인 대니얼이 출판을 강행한 이유에 관해서요

translation.en: She clearly hoped
that the manuscript was true,
but she clearly worried that it was not.
translation.ko: 하지만 진실이 아니라는 우려도 분명히 품고 있었습니다

translation.en: I think it was greed
that powered this narrative
for Misha and Jane Daniel.
And then, as those sales figures rose,
more and more people
accepted the memoir as real and as true.
[Jane] I admit it, I had created the monster.
translation.ko: 저도 인정해요 괴물을 만든 건 저라고요

translation.en: She was my monster.
I had created this person with enormous sympathy as a character.
translation.ko: 엄청난 동정심을 쏟아부어 하나의 캐릭터를 만들었어요

translation.en: Somebody who had suffered terribly.
Somebody who deserved respect and, in fact, awe.
translation.ko: 존경과 경외심의 대상이 되어 마땅한 사람으로요

translation.en: And nobody wants to admit that they were tricked.
translation.ko: 아무도 속았다는 걸 인정하려고 들지 않아요

translation.en: And I admit it, I was tricked by her, I believed her.
translation.ko: 전 인정해요 미샤에게 속았고, 미샤를 믿었어요

translation.en: Everybody was seduced.
The American jurisprudence system, the judges and the juries,
we were all seduced by the story.
[Evelyne] It's human to believe.
Credibility is something else.
It's your need to question if things are not
that will help you discern what's true and what's not true.
translation.ko: 질문을 던져야만 판별하는 데 도움을 받을 수 있어요

translation.en: [in French] You killed a human being with a knife?
Because I saw the rape of a little girl.
[Mommer, in French] I have enough distance
to take a more analytical look at Misha's character.
translation.ko: 미샤라는 인물을 바라볼 수 있게 됐어요

translation.en: When I saw that, I jumped because he turned and came towards me.
translation.ko: 그 순간 저는 펄쩍 뛰었어요 남자가 돌아보더니 다가왔거든요

translation.en: At that moment, I only thought about one thing,
to live.
Because I wanted to live.
Misha created a world for herself,
a world of her own belief.
When he was close, I stabbed him in the stomach.
translation.ko: 남자가 다가왔을 때 칼로 배를 찔렀어요

translation.en: I slashed everywhere.
The throat, the face.
I was covered in blood.
It was horrible.
Writing this book
has caused me to relive…
[voice breaking] …my nightmares.
[Mommer] Misha sought refuge in mythomania,
and with time,
she slowly becomes
a character in her own story.
Every time I stabbed,
it was for this little girl, it was for the children,
it was for my parents.
[in English] I think that we would like to believe
that Misha Defonseca believed
that she was a survivor of the Holocaust.
I think we would like to believe
that we were not so naive,
that we believed it because she believed it.
translation.ko: 그 사람이 그렇게 믿어서 우리도 믿어줬다는 식이죠

translation.en: And we would even like to believe
that this narrative has a redemptive purpose,
because it made right the wrong of her childhood.
translation.ko: 미샤가 어려서 겪은 고통이 상쇄됐을 거란 이유를 들죠

translation.en: I think it's nonsense.
There is no redemptive purpose.
We were so naive.
It was all a fabrication.
[Evelyne] How I feel about her today…
translation.ko: 지금 그 사람에 대한 감정이 어떠냐면…

translation.en: Mixed… Mixed emotions.
I think that she was a protagonist of this story, but she was not alone.
translation.ko: 이 사건의 주인공 같지만 단독 주인공은 아니에요

translation.en: There were other people that helped
to make this, uh, biography be a bestseller.
[Evelyne] Just talking about her right now, and the search,
translation.ko: 지금 미샤에 대해 말하다 보니 추적 과정과

translation.en: and the years that went by…
Some pity…
Some pity.
Some repulsion…
Maybe it's too hard a word, but…
I'm feeling some uh, understanding.
As a child, it must have been very difficult for her after the war,
translation.ko: 어린아이가 전쟁이 끝나고 몹시도 힘들었을 거예요

translation.en: the fact that her father was called a traitor, a collaborator.
translation.ko: 아버지는 배신자 소리를 들었죠 나치 부역자라고요

translation.en: She's both a victim and a villain.
She's both.
She is both in this story.
